card.title: ‘We should have better answers by now’: climate scientists baffled by unexpected pace of heating
card.description: The leap in temperatures over the past 13 months has exceeded the global heating forecasts – is this just a blip or a systemic shift?

descendants.content:
@Global_Repercussions @dan613
It's common in science to observe a phenomenon and realize the current model/ hypothesis/ theory doesn't explain it. Science is the process of recognizing that, and then figuring out what sort of experiment/ data gathering is needed to develop an explanation.

So the fact that "scientists can't explain it" only means that they need to do a bit of problem solving, not that anyone's guess is ok.

It's important to realize when one needs to gather more data, and to figure out what data is helpful in expanding our understanding

fields.name: pronouns
fields.value: he/him

descendants.content:
@PaulWermer @dan613
The article points out that many suspects have been examined and not explained the unexpected step change in reported temperatures over the past 13 months.

#elnino
#sulphuremissions reduction from shipping legislation
#watervapour from volcanic eruption of Hunga Tonga–Hunga Haʻapai, a submarine volcano in the Tongan archipelago in the southern Pacific Ocean.
#albedochange from reduced surface ice in #arctic, #Antarctic and other #glaciers

So, aside from all those here is my thought. The bulk of #atmospheric #greenhouseeffect occurs in the lowest 100 metres of the #troposphere. The bit of teh atmosphere closest to the ground, or #sealevel.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greenhouse_effect#:~:text=Each%20molecule%20in%20the%20air,can%20in%20the%20upper%20atmosphere.

https://www.readingma.gov/Faq.aspx?QID=172#:~:text=Atmospheric%20radiation%20is%20emitted%20to,is%20called%20the%20greenhouse%20effect.

There are going to be significant regional variations in the level of greenhouse gasses in the lower 100 metres of the atmosphere, effected by local emission sources. Especially melting #permafrost, #wetlands, leaking #oil and #gas wells and other things.

Models are using the aggregate global average CO2 and CO2 equivalent greenhouse gas measures to estimate temperature and climate outcomes. But short term, local and regional temperature increases will differ based on on local and regional CO2 equivalent greenhouse gas levels. Leading to overall accumulation of energy in the global system.

But, if we do need to take some time time to figure out in more detail and get general agreement as to what the fuck is going on, how about we have a #moratorium on producing greenhouse gases while we work it out? Start with say a month or two?

account.note:
I don't want to change the world.
Just the atmosphere and the oceans.

descendants.content:
@Global_Repercussions @PaulWermer @dan613

Wrt #Hungatonga and the past 13 months: Jucker et al mapped the multi-year effect of the water vapour on precipitation, temperature and jet stream in a detailed global grid.

Their layman's prose article says specifically that according to their results HungaTonga is no factor at all in the bananas phenomenon.
https://theconversation.com/tongas-volcanic-eruption-could-cause-unusual-weather-for-the-rest-of-the-decade-new-study-shows-231074

Obviously the past months pique everyone's curiosity and I see no reason why we should not speculate wildly what the reasons might be. We are The Society. The science law does not fall into our jurisdiction, so to speak. That people like Rahmstorf don't speculate if they can't back it up with sciency looking stuff – that's fine. I'd rather people like him not speculating without a sliver of attempted proof.
But this rule doesn't apply to us, The Society.

The land carbon sink net collapsed in 2023. A station in Australia Cape Grim https://capegrim.csiro.au received the signal in January 2024ff. Later than other stations due to delay in atmospheric mixing.

El Nino is a CO2-intense phase. One can sync the CO2 growth rate in the Cape Grim time series to, for example, the ElNino phase 2016 by moving the monthly growth values 8 months back. This sort of helps to triangulate the CO2 sources that arrive in Cape Grim during El Nino phases. Having done that, one sees that last year's Nino CO2 source arrived at Cape Grim earlier than the signals in other Nino years. This points to a CO2-origin that is close by in terms of atmospheric mixing. Close by = in the Southern Hemisphere.

So. The drought in the Amazon? Something like intensified ocean upwelling?
Or... was the mixing stronger and quicker this time than in 2016 or 1997?

account.note:
I know nothing of Snow and climate change. But its complexity is fascinating.
And how should our societies live within biophysical planetary boundaries?
*322ppm

media_attachments.description:
3 line charts with El Nino Index and CO2 growth in Cape Grim. Top chart original CO2 growth together with the MEI flavour of ENSO.
Middle chart is the same but moved 8 months back to sync with El Nino 2016. And as described in the post, in 2023/2024, the CO2 signal arrived 4 months earlier than El Nino began in reality. Whereas for example the CO2 signal in the 1997 El Nino arrived 4 months later, pointing to a CO2 source that is further away from Cape Grim in terms of atmospheric mixing. Further away than the 2016 source and also than the 2023/2024 source.  
Bottom chart is just the SST anomaly at ENSO3.4 and Cape Grim's CO2 growth synced to El Nino 2016.

descendants.content: @Global_Repercussions @PaulWermer This is what I mean: when you remove the natural influences, there isn't a statistically significant change in the trend over the course of data since 1990. There was an unusually cold period between 2012 and 2016. If you remove that period there is practically no change.

media_attachments.description: Two charts showing the difference of the global monthly temperature from the trend starting in 1990. The top one shows the raw data overlaid with the influence from solar, volcanoes, and El Niño, with the trend being 0.220℃/decade. The bottom one shows the data with the natural influences removed, overlaid with the 12 month moving average. The trend is 0.204℃/decade.

descendants.content:
@dan613 @PaulWermer

Are we differentiating between a concerning warming trend, an alarming warming trend, and/or a diabolically catstrophic warming trend.

As we are often lead to respond, we really wish you were right. Although you seem to be agreeing there is a long term and significant warming trend. Which I assume you agree is going to be an ongoing warmingbtren until global #greenhousegasemissions are reduced or stopped, and atmospheric #greenhousegas levels are reduced.

See how many more months this kind of thing keeps going on for.

https://www.noaa.gov/news/earth-just-had-its-warmest-july-on-record

Whichever trend state we confirm ourselves to be in, the task and the goal remains the same.

descendants.content:
@dan613 @PaulWermer

Control of our own actions, possibly? But that would be a key distinction between the powerful and the powerless.

Control of the global climate? I remain quite dubious of that proposition.

If we are in control of things I guess we could rapidly end plastic pollution? Or, the illicit trade in drugs?

That last one is a low bar, you just deciminalise or legalise all the drugs. Problem solved, at least the illicit trade part.

If we are in control, how come atmospheric CO2 levels are still growing at an increasing rate?
